Award.AwardTitle: Development and nanoscale characterization of back-gated topological devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this proposal is to establish the methodology to perform back-gated scanning tunneling microscopy on topological insulators, study these materials on a local scale with spectroscopy and gating, and to explore candidate materials for two-dimensional topological insulators. While gated STM has been highly successful in studying graphene, it has yet to be achieved in topological insulators.
The intellectual merit is the following. The ability to gate while performing STM will provide a tremendously powerful control knob to manipulate the properties of topological insulators and explore the role of interactions. The discovery of ultra thin films of topological insulators will be important to realizing the quantum spin hall effect.
The broader impacts are the following. Gated devices will provide the ability to position the Fermi energy near the Dirac point or away from the bulk bands and into the most interesting regimes for future applications. The edge modes at domain wall boundaries in 2D topological insulators are potentially useful for realizing one-dimensional dissipationless spin transport. Undergraduates, graduate students and post-docs will be trained on materials and instruments at the forefront of today?s research. The PI?s integrated outreach and education activities will expose talented high school students to cutting edge research. The program to effectively mentor post-doctoral scholars in the department will impact the training of future scientists. The PI?s ongoing collaboration with the Lynch School of Education will have a real measurable impact on the training and numbers of science teachers in middle- and high schools in urban areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the goals of the project was to create topological devices that can be gated from the back that would allow us to perform scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) measurements of the electronic structure with gating. Over the course of the project we have carried out all the necessary steps to achieve this. We have modified our sample holders and cabling to be able to provide the back gating voltage. During the course of the research we realized that to obtain clean surfaces for STM studies, the thin films should ideally be transported to the STM without breaking vacuum. To achieve this we have set up a molecular beam (MBE) epitaxy system in our lab. Thin films in our MBE system are grown on substrates attached to sample holders compatible with the STM such that they can be transferred into the STM without exposure to air using a vacuum suitcase. We have also started growing a subset of films in situ using an evaporator attached to the ultra high vacuum system, which is a part of out STM. A list of what we have accomplished is below:

  1. Assembled a homebuilt MBE system equipped with seven evaporators, RHEED, and sample annealing.
  2. Carried out growth of topological insulator thin films on insulating substrates. Checked film quality by AFM and X-ray. Developed recipe for epitaxial films as confirmed by x-ray diffraction.
  3. Developed the recipe to grow strained SnTe films on PbSe substrates and studied the films using scanning tunneling microscopy 
  4. Completed design and construction of the UHV vacuum suitcase and started the process of measuring these films by STM. Successfully obtained atomic resolution images and spectroscopy.

The newly developed MBE system has enabled us to grow thin films of various topological materials for future applications. The newly developed back-gated STM technology will allow us to access new regions of phase space in Topological insulators. These cutting edge technologies will help train a new generation of students.
